sn12.61:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. …
sn12.61:4.3: “Mendicants, when it comes to this body made up of the four elements, an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.61:4.5: This body made up of the four elements is seen to increase and decrease, to be taken up and laid to rest.
sn12.61:4.6: That’s why, when it comes to this body, an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.61:5.1: But when it comes to that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed.
sn12.61:5.3: Because for a long time they’ve been attached to it, thought of it as their own, and mistaken it:
sn12.61:5.4: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn12.61:5.5: That’s why, when it comes to this mind, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.61:6.1: But an uneducated ordinary person would be better off taking as self this body made up of the four elements, rather than the mind.
sn12.61:6.3: This body made up of the four elements is seen to last for a year, or for two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred years, or even longer.
sn12.61:7.1: But that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
sn12.61:7.2: It’s like a monkey moving through the forest. It grabs hold of one branch, lets it go, and grabs another; then it lets that go and grabs yet another.
sn12.61:7.3: In the same way, that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
sn12.61:8.1: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully focuses on sources in the context of dependent origination itself:
sn12.61:8.2: ‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.
sn12.61:8.3: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
sn12.61:8.4: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
sn12.61:8.5: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn12.61:8.6: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn12.61:8.7: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
sn12.61:8.9: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
sn12.61:9.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn12.61:9.2: Being disillusioned they become dispassionate. Being dispassionate they’re freed. When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn12.61:9.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
